Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Cooperative Supramolecular Polymerization from Polypeptide-containing Macromolecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Supramolecular chemistry has made great progress in assembling small molecules capable of coordinated, non-covalent interactions into supramolecular structures. However, success in the use of large synthetic macromolecules as the monomer units for supramolecular polymerization has been limited. As inferred from supramolecular polymers from proteins, giant polymeric superstructures can be constructed from macromolecular monomers, and they are expected to have remarkable material performance and superior stability. The objective of this CAREER research is to develop synthetic macromolecules that undergo controlled supramolecular polymerization to form nanomaterials with predictable morphology and physical properties. The approach begins with investigations of synthetic macromolecules bearing grafted polypeptides, and takes advantage of the predictable interactions among grafted polypeptide secondary structures to drive the assembly. The research seeks to: (1) synthesize supramolecular polymers from selected polypeptide-grafted comb macromolecules and characterize their structures, (2) characterize the mechanical properties of supramolecular polymers and elucidate the molecular basis of the properties, (3) conduct kinetic and thermodynamic studies to establish the cooperative assembly mechanisms in the supramolecular polymerization from macromolecular units, and (4) deduce the general principles involved in the design of synthetic macromolecular units for cooperative assembly and polymerizations. The proposed research could ultimately lead to the generation of polymeric systems that will approach the level of sophistication and complexity found in nature?s self-organized supramolecular polymers.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The remarkable physical properties of nanostructures assembled from biological macromolecules have long inspired scientists to create synthetic systems that work with similar precision and efficiency. Practical design of biologically inspired synthetic materials has emerged at the interface of polymer science, chemistry and biology, and may find applications in sustainable plastics, biomedical materials and renewable energy. The proposed research will create new macromolecular building blocks for controlled assembly, provide insights into the assembly mechanisms, and develop nanostructured materials with superior mechanical strength and self-healing properties. The growth of polymer research at such an interface provides opportunities to educate students and inspire them to pursue careers in science and engineering. The CAREER award will allow the PI to develop an integrated research and education program on Bioinspired Polymeric Materials at University of Connecticut. The program will address students' major needs for interdisciplinary education and high quality research experiences in this emerging field. The proposed outreach program seeks to: (1) integrate the proposed research with the development of interdisciplinary polymer courses; (2) provide vibrant polymer research experiences to undergraduates and high-school students and (3) promote polymer research and its impact on society through providing lectures for the general public. Emphasis will be given to involve underrepresented students at all levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supramolecular chemistry has made great progress in assembling small molecules capable of coordinated interactions into supramolecular structures. However, success in the use of large synthetic macromolecules as the monomer units for supramolecular polymerization has been limited. As inferred from supramolecular polymers made from proteins, giant polymeric superstructures can be constructed from macromolecular monomers, and they are expected to have remarkable material performance and superior stability. This CAREER research grant was to develop a general, bioinspired strategy for controlled supramolecular polymerization from large macromolecules for material applications. Supported by this grant, the PI’s lab has elucidated: (1) the structure and morphology of the supramolecular assemblies from a class of synthetic polypeptide-containing complex macromolecules, (2) the design principles and thermodynamic analysis of the assembly in aqueous solution, (3) the methodology to regulate the supramolecular polymerization and to quantitatively analyze the kinetics of the complex processes, and (4) the importance of balancing a subtle trade-off between structure and dynamics to control polymorphism of resulting supramolecular polymers. In addition, the PI’s lab has reported how the cooperative interactions induced by macromolecular architectures may profoundly change the chain configuration and associations of polypeptides in the macromolecules, and in the case of α-helical polypeptides, even catalyze its own formation in the polymerization process. New statistical mechanical model and nucleation-controlled kinetic models have been developed in these works to describe the cooperative effects induced by the macromolecular architecture. The understanding of the “non-local” interactions of polypeptides also led the PI’s lab to challenge a classic phase diagram predicted by Zimm and Bragg, and went on to prove that, both in theory and in experiments, long “all-helix” chains are much less prevalent than previously imagined. These works have been well received, with two articles featured on the cover of JACS and Nature Chemistry, respectively.

With the NSF support, three graduate students have defended their Ph.D. thesis successfully, and seven undergraduate students and one high school student were trained in the lab. The PI has given 25+ invited national/international talks and seminars to present the research achievement made possible by the CAREER grant and disseminated the knowledge. The PI has actively incorporated new knowledge into the Polymer Characterization class he taught, and developed a new graduate course of “Polymerization in Life and Life-Inspired Systems”. The PI has organized or co-organized the UConn SECRET (School of Exploratory Chemistry Research Experience & Training) program for three times in the summers of 2012-2014. A total of 30 high school students attended and benefited from the one-week research camp. By partnering with John Hopkins Center for Talented Youth (CTY), the PI has organized the STEM workshop of “Chemical Approaches to Nanomaterials” at UConn on March 16, 2014, and again on March 12, 2016. A total of 193 middle/high school students and their parents from 10 different home states attended the one-day workshop to learn about fundamental concepts in nanochemistry and nanomaterials through a combination of short talks and hands-on activities. The PI has organized a symposium “Research at the interface between chemistry and biology” at UConn, which is supported by the Office of Vice President for Research and open to all members at UConn and local science teachers. The PI has led an effort to establish collaborations with Fudan and Shanghai Jiaotong Universities in China, in the areas of Polymer and Chemistry. 25+ undergraduate students from the three schools have been supported by the program to have research experience abroad.
